TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {1509=In 1794, George Willig (1764-1851) took over the Philadelphia-based (John Christopher) Moller & (Henri) Capron, which was founded in 1793 and was the first music publisher in America. Willig operated the firm until his death; it was taken over by Lee & Walker in 1856., 1858=In 1822, Willig acquired the Baltimore publisher Thomas Carr, which his son (George Jr. [1794-1874, not 1879]) ran from 1829 until his death. It continued to operate under the same name after his death.}
textBeforeTable: George Willig (Philadelphia) (Note: Only George Willig Jr. appeared to put plate numbers on its scores.) Plate Numbers Baltimore: George Willig & Co. (after about 1870 or so.) Baltimore: George Willig Jr. - 197 Baltimore St. (in 1847 e.g.) Philadelphia: George Willig - 171 Chestnut St. Imprints and Addresses In 1822, Willig acquired the Baltimore publisher Thomas Carr, which his son (George Jr. [1794-1874, not 1879]) ran from 1829 until his death. It continued to operate under the same name after his death. In 1794, George Willig (1764-1851) took over the Philadelphia-based (John Christopher) Moller & (Henri) Capron, which was founded in 1793 and was the first music publisher in America. Willig operated the firm until his death; it was taken over by Lee & Walker in 1856.
